awd_titl_txt: Computational Characterizaion of Non-covalent Clusters with New and Existing Methods
awd_abstract_narration:
In this project funded by the Chemical Structure, Dynamics and Mechanisms-A (CSDM-A) and Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry (MSN) programs of the Division of Chemistry, Professor Greg Tschumper of the University of Mississippi is using computational tools based on quantum mechanics (QM) to model and study clusters of molecules held together by weak interactions.  It is weak interactions that cause atoms and molecules stick to each other without actually forming chemical bonds.  Weak interactions include hydrogen bonding, halogen bonding, and London dispersion forces. These computations complement ongoing experimental investigations ranging from fundamental studies of solvation to the design, synthesis and characterization of new molecules, nano-scale assemblies and materials.  More broadly, the impact of this work includes accelerating the development of novel materials with potential societal benefits (e.g., clean energy, drug delivery, and compact flexible electronics). This research program has a positive impact on the education and training of science students from underrepresented groups at the graduate and undergraduate levels. Through a collaboration with Professor Jeremy Carr of Central Alabama Community College (CACC), Professor Tschumper provides research experiences for community college students.

The project is divided into two parts, the first of which employs well-calibrated methods based on both density functional theory (DFT) and wave function theory (WFT) to a series of computational investigations devised to facilitate experimental characterization(spectroscopic, crystallographic, etc.).  The methods make reliable predictions that can aid efforts to design and synthesize new molecules, nano-structures and materials.  The second aspect of the research concentrates on the continued development of the N-body : Many-body integrated QM : QM methodology to enable the routine application of high-accuracy QM techniques to larger non-covalent clusters with modest computational resources like those often found in individual research labs or small departments. Emphasis is placed on evaluating spectroscopic properties (e.g.,anharmonic vibrational frequencies and NMR chemical shifts) of non-covalent clusters with systematically convergent techniques within the N-body : Many-body framework as well as extending the accuracy and efficiency of the approach to molecular aggregates containing open-shell, ionic and excited state species.

por.por_cntn:
The relatively weak, non-covalent interactions between the components of molecular clusters are of the utmost importance in many areas of chemistry, biology, physics and engineering, and they provided the underlying motivation for this research project. Computational chemistry continues to play a vital role in understanding these interactions as well as the chemical phenomena they influence. This research program focused on the computational characterization of molecular clusters held together by weak non-covalent interactions (e.g., hydrogen bonding, halogen bonding and π-stacking) with robust quantum mechanical (QM) electronic structure methods. Emphasis was placed on the evaluation of spectroscopic signatures of these interactions to facilitate direct comparison to experimental measurements.

One of the most significant products from this NSF sponsored research has been the development and application of the N-body:Many-body (Nb:Mb) computational method to accurately model these non-covalent clusters. The analytic Hessians developed for the Nb:Mb approach have now been coupled with second-order vibrational perturbation theory (VPT2), which has broadened the impact of the work by allowing researchers to compute fundamental vibrational frequencies that can be directly compared to experimental spectra. This approach significantly reduces the computational demands of the most reliable QM models so that the necessary computations can be performed routinely on modest computational resources, like those often found in individual research groups or small chemistry departments at primarily undergraduate institutions, rather than requiring a large supercomputer.

Another key outcome highlighting the intellectual merit of this project came from an experimental and theoretical collaboration that provided the first detailed experimental characterization of the intermolecular vibrations for the water trimer. Water is arguably the most important substance on our planet. For example, it plays a vital role in many chemical processes in our bodies and in the atmosphere. Its unique properties stem from the subtle ways the individual H2O molecules interact with each other and with other chemical species when they are dissolved. Water is so familiar to us that many of its unusual properties go unnoticed. The solid is less dense than the liquid (ice floats on water), and the liquid actually contracts, rather than expands, when heated at temperatures near freezing. High-level QM electronic structure computations, made feasible by the aforementioned Nb:Mb capabilities, facilitated the interpretation of the experimental spectra. This research has helped tease out important details behind the origins of this amazing behavior by providing novel details about how the interactions between a pair of water molecules are influenced by the presence of a third. More broadly, these results can be used to better understand and predict the behavior of water under different conditions. In turn, this could help improve existing theoretical models for simulating aqueous chemistry.

Additional broader impacts include an ongoing collaboration with a chemistry instructor at a community college for which the PI has provided the instructor and his students with remote access to computational chemistry software and the necessary hardware to carry out quantum mechanical electronic structure computations for education and research. The project is also contributing to the development of a technically skilled workforce.  During the project period, a number of graduate, undergraduate and high school students received training in the PI?s lab on computational quantum chemistry, programming techniques, technical writing and scientific communication. This team has disseminated results from this research project through multiple peer-reviewed publications in chemistry journals as well as numerous scientific presentations at professional meetings and at other research institutions. The highly accurate properties (dissociation energies, infrared vibrational spectra, etc.) being computed in the PIs lab are not only being used to reassign experimental results but also provide benchmark data for the calibration and validation of less demanding computational methods.
